items.content_html:
Description

Smoothly animate seconds hand in the clock in the Animated Clock example for canvas. Sample video below:

Screen.Recording.2023-09-08.at.5.39.29.AM.mp4

Motivation

To properly showcase the fact that the canvas is drawn 60 times per second, the second hand in the clock now smoothly moves instead of jumping from tick to tick (once per second).

Additional details

  • Applies to: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Canvas_API/Tutorial/Basic_animations#an_animated_clock
  • Tested using MDN Playground.

Related issues and pull requests

None

PS: Please use "Squash and Merge"; thank you.
items.title: Smoothly animate seconds hand in the clock

items.content_html:
We don't mention subgrid or nesting grids in the learn doc, this PR adds some more examples and links to subgrid where possible.

additions:

  • nested grid example
  • example using subgrid
  • link to subgrid in See Also

changes:

  • Height of embedded examples to make vertical space a little tighter
  • Some flyby tidy up

follow-ups:
It might be nice to add the example with nested grids to be available to download in the learning area. Pending review changes on that.
items.title: docs(css): Add details about subgrid to Grid Learn article

items.content_html:
Description

Enhancing the example in the documentation for seekforward and seekbackward events when using Media Session API The changes include the explicit introduction of the seekOffset property within the event object passed to the respective event callback functions. These modifications offer developers a clearer understanding of the seekOffset property, providing crucial information about the user's seek actions. Additionally, the updated example acknowledges that if the seekOffset property is absent in the event, developers can gracefully default to a predefined seek value, typically 10 seconds.

Motivation

When setting an action handler for the seekforward or seekbackward events, the main piece of information the developers are looking for is how many seconds the user seeks forward or backwards, essentially, the number of seconds to seek. If this information is not readily available, developers can fall back to a fixed seek value, such as 10 seconds.

However, I encountered an issue when referencing the example provided in the documentation. The example consistently used a fixed 10-second seek time and did not utilize the seekOffset property at all. This omission caused confusion for me, as it was not clear how to obtain the essential seekOffset information when listening to these events.
items.title: Clarify Media Session API Example: Highlight the Use of `seekOffset` Property in `seekforward` and `seekbackward` Events

items.content_html:
See this codepen: https://codepen.io/sidewayss/pen/qBLqPPa

  1. floating point numbers are rounded to integers in the rgb() function, so there's no point in using them.
  2. hsl() and hwb() are converted to rgb by the browser and are limited to integer values in rgb(), although achieving whole number changes in rgb() can require fractional changes in the other two functions.

I did not mention 2) in either the hsl or hwb page, though I took a crack at it in the RGB glossary page. I am also not familiar with the various RGB color spaces, but in the CSS color() function, the Adobe a98-rgb color space is represented by a "fractional value" (aka unit interval) between 0 and 1. Not sure how that fits in with this paragraph in the RGB glossary page:

Note that there are other RGB color spaces, like the Adobe RGB color space, that can represent a wider {{glossary("gamut")}} of color than the sRGB color space. The coordinates in sRGB and Adobe RGB are different.

I just committed some edits to the color() function page. CSS needs a more generic type for "number between 0 and 1", or does it exist and I'm unaware of it? <alpha-value> is identical to what is needed, but it is specified as belonging to the alpha value, not opacity or any of the other properties/functions that take a number between 0 and 1 or a <percentage>.
items.title: Detail about <number>s in rgb-related color functions and glossary

items.content_html:
We don't have a template for CSS functions (or CSS types, see #26881), and the way we document them is quite inconsistent:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/basic-shape/polygon
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform-function/matrix
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/sign
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/min
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/pow
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/var

Some choices I've made here:

  1. the syntax example only includes the function itself, not a complete declaration (i.e. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/var#syntax , not https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/pow#syntax
  2. uses "Parameters" and "Return value", not "Values" (i.e. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/pow#parameters, not https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/var#values)

The reasoning for 1 is that including declarations leads us into conversations like #28873 (review), and I wonder if this will be confusing when we inevitably omit some of the properties that the function can provide a value for.

Happy to discuss though. @yarusome , what do you think?
items.title: Add a template for CSS functional notation

items.content_html:
Description

The charset for the realm directive is undefined and thus only us-ascii is really reliably supported.

Motivation

I accidentally set the realm value to a UTF-8 encoded value and was surprised by the result. While debugging this I noticed that at least Firefox and Chromium do not show this value anymore at all.

Additional details

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7617#section-3
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110#section-11.5

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update realm restrictions

items.content_html:
Description

The match would sometimes fail due to the VARY header.

Motivation

For a tutorial, it's very important to be as safe as possible, so request.url should be used instead of request.

Additional details

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42813582/service-worker-cache-matchrequest-returns-undefined
items.title: Improved the reliability of cache.match by using an url instead of a request

items.title: Add conditional spreads documentation to spread documentation

items.content_html:
Add explicit text about the inability to use setDragImage and setData when dragging files into the browser from the OS, as dragstart is never fired.

Description

The File drag and drop page is a great overview of how to build a barebones file drop handler. But it lacks a specific note about this particular limitation.

Motivation

I hope to prevent others from having to figure this out the hard/time-consuming way, as I did.
items.title: Update “File drag and drop” doc to mention inability to use setDragImage and setData when dragging files into the browser from the OS

items.content_html:
Fixes #28866.

This makes a few changes to the page for polygon(), including:

  • more informative summary
  • more syntax examples to show you can use more than just percentages
  • rewritten "Values" section to add links
  • added "Formal syntax"
  • turned GH sample into a live sample, which is a lot more readable (wrt this we have expressed a desire to move away from GHLiveSample when we can, and towards EmbedLiveSample)
  • made some minor changes to the example to (I hope) make it more understandable

If you like these changes we should do something similar with the other <basic-shape> functions.
items.title: Fix 28866: Clarify polygon() syntax

items.content_html:
Description

This PR adds a new section to the autocomplete attribute documentation, explaining the usage of tokens and sections. It provides examples of how to use this component to specify autofill details for different sections of a form.

Motivation

This addition would help readers gain a better understanding of how to effectively use the autocomplete attribute.

Additional details

This is the page that I'm working with: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/autocomplete

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #28636
Relates to #20180
items.title: feat: add information on tokens and sections

items.content_html:
We are using "local/global" terminology here as an analogy which I think may be adding some confusion. We already define coordinate systems under "screen" and "client" coordinates which aligns with current specs, so I would remove the ambiguity and refer to those definitions only instead.

Fixes #28676
items.title: chore(API): Clarify local/global coordinates refer to client / screen coords
